Parents of Students Eligible for Free Lunch

Your students are eligible to receive free high-speed internet service through the Alabama Broadband Connectivity for Students Program. You will receive a letter sometime after August 24. It will have your prepaid voucher number, which you can use for free high speed internet service through December 30, 2020, and a list of internet service providers that you can call to set up your service.

Once you receive your voucher letter, follow the steps below to get your students ready to participate in distance learning this fall. You will not be able to start the program until you receive the voucher letter.

Program Details:

Your voucher covers the cost of equipment, installation fees, and internet service through December 30, 2020.
Activation steps vary by internet service provider.
You can use your voucher one time only, as described in the letter. It cannot be used in a retail store.
If your address is incorrect, call your student’s school. Eligibility for the Alabama Broadband Connectivity for Students Program is based on enrollment in the National School Lunch Program, which is handled by your child’s school.

About the Alabama Broadband Connectivity for Students Program:
Governor Kay Ivey has committed $100 million in Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act funding to deliver free internet access to eligible K-12 students in their homes this fall. The State of Alabama is using the funds to purchase internet service for low-income households with K-12 students so students can participate in distance learning. This service is being administered through the Alabama Broadband Connectivity for Students Program.

Students in Alabama that are enrolled in the National School Lunch Program through their school are automatically eligible for the Alabama Broadband Connectivity for Students Program. The letter you will receive serves as a prepaid voucher from the Alabama Broadband Connectivity for Students Program and covers the cost of equipment, installation, and high-speed internet service through December 30, 2020. The voucher can be used once, with one internet service provider, to sign up for service for the duration of the program. Enrolled households will not receive any bills and will not be charged any additional fees by the internet service provider.

If the address for your student has changed, please contact their school to update their address for the National School Lunch Program.

The voucher is intended for students who are eligible for the National School Lunch Program. By using the voucher, you will be confirming that you meet the income requirements of the National School Lunch Program, which is limited to households earning $48,470 or less for a family of four. Please do not use the voucher if your household is not income eligible for the National School Lunch Program. Your attention to this will help ensure that households that need help connecting will receive it.

Do you have questions or need assistance in Spanish?
Call the Alabama Broadband Connectivity for Students Program at 1-888-212-4998 or visit their website at www.abcstudents.org (website also available in Vietnamese and Lao).

- We are asking parents to monitor for fever and COVID-19 symptoms at home.

- Students may bring a facial covering from home. Masks may be provided while supplies last.

- Adult access to school facilities will be limited. Parents should stay in their vehicles during drop off and pick up and not enter the school buildings.

- Parent-teacher conferences will be held virtually.

DCSS to Partner with U.S.D.A. and Baylor University for Free Student Meals in June.

Demopolis City School System still wants to provide food and nutrition to our students even during this time while school is closed, so we’re announcing a new program that will deliver meals at your doorstep for free. This program is called Meals-to-You, and it is a partnership between our district, the U.S. Department of Agriculture, and Baylor University. Your student(s) enrolled in the Demopolis City School System are eligible to participate in the program.

When you sign up to get a Meals-to-You, every other week you’ll get a Meals-to-You box delivered to your home for each child 1-18 in your household. Each box will include 10 breakfasts and 10 lunches/suppers—enough food for each kid for two weeks!

All foods are shelf stable, which means you don’t have to worry about them expiring anytime soon. With Meals-to-You, kid-friendly meals are delivered—for FREE—directly to your door, so you don’t have to worry about:
• Extra trips to the grocery store
• Extra money spent on food
• Extra time planning meals your kids will like

If you aren’t home when the box is delivered, no worries. The boxes are packed for security, and because the food is shelf stable, you don’t have to worry about refrigerating the foods immediately. If you will be unable to pick up your box(es) on a given day, be sure to have a neighbor or family get it. And no need to worry; receiving this benefit will NOT affect any other existing benefits.

HOW DO YOU SIGN UP? All you have to do is fill out an online sign-up form and submit it as soon as possible! Access the online form by clicking this link:

https://mealstoyou.org/emergency-meals-to-you-application/

Boxes will be provided on a first come, first served basis, so sign up online today! Let Meals-to-You take away the stress of buying extra groceries during this time. If you have questions or would like more information, please contact Aretha Littles at 334-289-1721.

Enrollment Information and Forms can be found at https://www.dcsedu.com/

Demopolis Residents
If you live in Demopolis and are registering for school for the first time in our system, you will need to complete the 20-21 DCS Enrollment Application. The address on the identification will need to match the addresses on the proofs of residency. Examples of proofs of residency include utility bills, lease agreements, or mortgage statements (we are not interest in your payment, only your address).

Non-Demopolis Residents
If you do not live in Demopolis and are registering for the first time in our system, you will need to complete a Non-Resident Application Form. Make sure it is complete and the information is accurate. With this completed form, you also will need to provide two (2) proofs of residency and a copy of the child’s legal guardian’s identification. The address on the identification will need to match the addresses on the proofs of residency. Examples of proofs of residency include utility bills, lease agreements, or mortgage statements (we are not interest in your payment, only your address). Non-resident students entering the Demopolis City School System for the first time will also need to include a transcript/grades from the previous school, with the exception of Kindergarten students entering school for the first time. Students will be conditionally accepted pending the review of grades and the application. The Demopolis City School System charges a $50.00 fee for non-resident applications and only accepts non-resident students in grade-levels and programs where space is available.



Submitting Enrollment Forms
Enrollment forms and supporting documentation can be submitted 3 ways.
1. Delivered to the applicable school. However, due to COVID-19 this option is not currently available.
2. Scanned and emailed. Completed forms and all supporting documentation can be scanned and emailed to questions@dcsedu.com.
3. Mailed to the applicable school(s)

Demopolis, AL 36732

701 U.S. Hwy. 80
Demopolis, AL 36732

It is important to remember, that non-resident applications are conditionally accepted until all documentation is received and reviewed. The school system reserves the right to remove non-resident students who falsify information on the application or accumulate attendance and discipline concerns once in our school system.

A letter from Superintendent Kallhoff.

April 6, 2020

Parents and Stakeholders,

Let me begin by pleading with you to practice social distancing, good hygiene habits, and adhering to the “Stay at Home Order” issued by Governor Ivey on Saturday, April 4th, 2020. In education, everything we do is based on students and interaction with children and adolescents. The COVID-19 pandemic, that has literally stopped our world, has educators across the nation scrambling to meet the educational, social, and emotional needs of our students in ways that are new and uncommon. Please know over the next 5 weeks, we will do our best to support you and your children in closing out this school year productively and we can only pray that things will be back to normal later this summer as we will be preparing for the 2020-2021 school year. Below are important details from our state approved Academic Continuity Plan that begins on Monday, April 13, 2020.

Remote Learning
Remote learning packets can be picked up curbside at each campus on Thursday (April 9th) and Friday (April 10th) from 8:00 to 3:00. Do not exit your vehicle when picking up these packets.

Each school is preparing five week instructional packets. These packets will include a pacing guide to help families navigate through the learning at a pace that is appropriate for the students. This same information will be available at each school’s website in a tab titled Remote Learning.

In grades K-3 there will be a paper packet for every child. In grades 4-11 (and applicable seniors), paper packets will be available, however on-line resources are encouraged. Google Classroom will be the platform used for on-line instruction. If your child has difficulties entering Google Classroom, you will need to contact his or her teacher.

It is important that students complete and do the best they can with the remote learning. The completion of this 5-week packet, either on-line or paper packet, will help determine placement, intervention, and enrichment decisions we make for the 2020-2021 school year. Remote learning, either on-line or paper packet, are to be completed by May 15, 2020. We will announce a procedure for returning the paper packets at a later date.

Communication and Support
Teachers are available via email Monday through Friday from 8:00 AM to 3:00 PM. General questions can be emailed to questions@dcsedu.com and we will respond as soon as possible. You may also email the principals with questions.

School Principal’s Email
WES tlewis@dcsedu.com

U.S. Jones bpowell@dcsedu.com

DMS dhester@dcsedu.com

DHS bhathcock@dcsedu.com

Hours of Operation
Due to the “Stay at Home” order issued by Governor Ivey on Saturday, April 4, 2020, we will be closing all school offices immediately. We will re-open when it is safe to do so.
On behalf of the Board of Education, Faculty and Staff, we appreciate your partnership more than ever. Whereas keeping up with school work is important, you and your family’s health, wellness, and safety will always be the number one priority. Remember, love and faith are our constants and love and faith will get us through these difficult times.

Kyle Kallhoff
Superintendent of Education
Demopolis City School System

Parents and Stakeholders,

We appreciate your patience and partnership as we continue to work through this unprecedented chain of events. Now more than ever we need a strong partnership to support our students. Below you will find an outline of the plan we will use in our system. Keep in mind, we are on spring break next week. Take this time to prepare your children for the next 6 weeks and hopefully by the end of May, things will get back to normal.

Demopolis City School System COVID-19 School Closure Plan

School Facilities
Schools will not be open until further notice.
Board employees will not have face to face interaction until further notice.

Student Feeding Program
Due to spring break we will not be serving March 30th – April 3rd.
Beginning April 6th, we will continue to operate two sites (Westside and Jones).
We will serve from 10:30 to 12:30 Monday through Friday.
We will continue this service until we feel it becomes a danger to our employees (by monitoring the cases of coronavirus in our immediate area).

Seniors (class of 2020)
We will identify those seniors who needed 4th quarter to graduate.
Those identified will receive a computer and hotspot when they are available.
They will be contacted by the high school and will take the needed course work via ACCESS (state provided method of on-line delivery) or another state provided method of on-line delivery of instruction.
Seniors who were on track to graduate without the assistance of 4th quarter will be issued a diploma (except for those taking AP courses and Dual Enrollment).
We will schedule a graduation when the CDC says it is safe to host a gathering of people.
Will not be before June 5th (Most likely in July).

School Athletics
All School athletics are cancelled this spring (not postponed).
We will not have gatherings of students prior to June 5th.
We will not gather students until the CDC says it is safe to do so.

Academics
K-8 Critical Standards will be covered between April 13th and May 15th.
On-line lessons on those identified standards (using google classroom) will be available from each school.
For those without internet access, paper packets on those identified standards will be available to be picked up at each school.
A pacing guide will be provided.

9-12 courses standards will be identified that have not been covered after 3 quarters and will be covered between April 13th and May 15th.
On-line lessons on those identified standards (using google classroom) will be available.
For those without internet access, paper packets on those identified standards will be available to be picked up at the high school.
A pacing guide will be provided.
Links will be posted to free ACT Prep resources for enrichment.
Dual Enrollment and AP Courses will be web-based and those students have been contacted by the staff.
All paper packets will be available for pick-up from 8:00 AM to 3:00 PM at each school on April 9th and 10th. Do not exit your vehicle, this will be a grab and go process.
These packets will be due back to the school on Monday, May 18th.

Teacher Assistance and Support
At a minimum, teachers are available via email Monday through Friday 8:00 AM to 3:00 PM. Teachers will set virtual office hours to support students which will be announced at each school.

Grades
Students in jeopardy of failing will be contacted by each school.
For these students, completed packets and/or Google Classroom forms will be used in determining if students are promoted to the next grade-level.
In order to ensure that your child is prepared for the next grade-level or subject, it is imperative that these assignments/packets are completed.

Additional Support
Parents can email questions@dcsedu.com if they have questions or need additional information. We will do our best to answer these questions

Social Distancing
Continue to practice good hygiene habits, avoid gatherings, and stay home if you can.

Helpful Tips to Ease Anxiety in School-Aged Children Regarding the Coronavirus Pandemic

Facing the unknown is frightening for anyone, but even more so for children. At the present time there is much fear regarding the Coronavirus Pandemic. This information is provided to assist with conversations you may have with your children.
Important Tips:
• Take care of yourself first. Children depend on the adults around them to be and to feel safe and secure. If you are very anxious or angry, children are more likely to be affected by your emotional state than by your words.
• Children may need extra attention from you and may want to talk about their concerns, fears, and questions. It is important that they know they have someone who will listen to them; make time for them.
• Talk about the Coronavirus Pandemic with your students if you feel it is appropriate – only provide information that is CORRECT and age appropriate for children. Do NOT repeat information to students that is not factual. Provide specific information: Example: “This is a respiratory illness spread by coughing and sneezing.” “The CDC states these symptoms appear in a few days after being exposed to someone with the disease or as long as 14 days after exposure: 1. Fever 2. Cough 3. Shortness for breath. For some people the symptoms are like having a cold; for others they are quite severe. Your parents will need to contact your health care provider for any specific concerns”
• Advise older children that everything they see/read on the internet is not necessarily factual. Tell them that the Centers for Disease Control and Alabama Department of Public Health provides the most up to date information.
• Reassure children of the steps that are being taken to keep them safe. Provide specific information: “We are all going to be very careful to cover our coughs and sneezes by coughing/sneezing in our elbow”. “We must all wash our hands or use hand sanitizer often”. “Everyone should try to practice social distancing – which is to stay 6 feet away from others when possible.” “We are keeping our classroom clean to decrease the spread of germs at school.”
More detailed information is available on the CDC website.

Demopolis City School System Parents/Guardians,

The leaders and administration of the Demopolis City School System are operating under the guidance of the Alabama State Department of Education and the Alabama Department of Public Health in regards to the 2019 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19). At this time, we are not aware of any Coronavirus cases in our school system or the area which we serve. At this point, we are asking you to take similar safety precautions that one would take during flu season. Below are a few reminders and tips that can help us be proactive and keep our students safe from viruses.

Stay Home When Sick

1. Students and staff who have symptoms of acute respiratory illness should stay home and not come to school until they are free of fever (100 degrees or greater using an oral thermometer), signs of a fever, and any other symptoms for at least 24 hours, without the use of fever reducing or other symptom-altering medicines.

2. Seek immediate medical care if symptoms become severe, such as high fever or difficulty breathing.

Use Respiratory Etiquette

1. Cover cough with a tissue or sleeve.
2. Keep tissues within easy reach and use no-touch trash cans.
3. Routinely clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces and objects.
4. Wash hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. Use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer if soap and water are not available.
5. Avoid touching face with unwashed hands.
6. Avoid close contact with people who are sick.

For more information you can contact ADPH at (334) 206-5971 or visit the ADPH website at http://alabamapublichealth.gov/infectiousdiseases/2019-coronovirus.gov

Parents,
Flu season is here and we need a strong partnership to prevent a widespread in our schools. Below are some tips recently released from our Health Services Department to help keep the flu contained. If your child is absent due to the flu, make sure they return with a Doctor’s Excuse. If you chose not to go to the Doctor, make sure they return with a Parent Excuse that says, (Student’s Name) was absent due to flu like symptoms. During this flu season we will allow up to 4 Parent Excuses stating that the child was absent with flu like symptoms. These 4 flu like symptom Parent Excuses will not count toward the 5 allowed Parent Excuses per year. We will use a special code when entering the Parent Excuses due to flu like symptoms in our attendance system.

Keep your child at home for treatment and observation if he or she has any of the following symptoms:
· Fever (greater than 99 degrees during flu season) Your child may return to school only after his or her temperature has been consistently below 99 degrees, by mouth for a minimum of 24 hours without the use of Tylenol or Motrin.
· Vomiting (even once)
· Diarrhea
· Chills
· General malaise or feelings of fatigue, discomfort, weakness or muscle aches
· Frequent congested (wet) or croupy cough
· Lots of nasal congestion with frequent blowing of nose

To help prevent the flu and other colds, teach your children good hygiene habits:
· Wash hands frequently
· Do not touch eyes, nose or mouth
· Cover mouth and nose when sneezing or coughing
· Avoid close contact with people who are sick
· Wipe down hard surfaces and door knobs with disinfectant wipes and spray

Colds and influenza are most contagious during the first 48 hours. A child who has started antibiotics needs to be on the medication for 48 hours before they are considered non-contagious and able to return to school. Often when a child awakens with vague complaints (the way colds and flu begin), it is wise to observe your child at home for an hour or two before deciding whether or not to bring them to school. Please do not send your child to school with instructions to go to the nurse or dose them with Tylenol or Motrin to suppress their fever. Please make arrangements to have a caregiver available in case your child becomes ill while in school and keep your child’s emergency contact list current. Your child should be physically able to participate in all school activities once they return to school. Keeping a sick child at home will help minimize the spread of infections and viruses in the classroom.

The grant application was written by gifted teacher, Dana Hill, and will support place-based education in Demopolis and the surrounding areas. The grant is titled “The Town Becomes the Classroom”, and is designed to explore and appreciate the rich history and wonderful resources of Demopolis, Alabama. According to Mrs. Hill, “through this grant the students will learn spirally by taking the classroom into the community and bringing the community into the classroom”.

This week’s Demopolis Difference Maker is the 2019 River City Blue. This group of young people experienced the loss of two fellow band members, classmates, and friends. Processing the death of a loved one is difficult for adults, but unimaginable for adolescents. Still, this group has proven to be resilient and supportive of each other in an inconceivable way. The norm in education is for adults to teach students, but oftentimes it is the opposite. Watching this group over the past week has reminded adults how to love, pray, reflect, remember, support and strengthen bonds that may never be broken. This is best summarized in the book of Romans where Paul explains how suffering leads to hope. Suffering produces perseverance, perseverance produces character, and character produces hope.
Thank You River City Blue,

post_text: Have you ever met Avake? He is a senior at DHS and a student athlete. Last week he bought a $15 homecoming shirt from the cheerleaders . He paid with a $20 bill and was given $5 change at the time of the purchase. When the shirts arrived, the cheer sponsor gave Avake his shirt and $5 change (thinking he was still owed $5 from the purchase). Within minutes, it dawned on him that he was not owed change and he returned the $5 bill to the cheer sponsor. In a situation like this, some people would just keep the $5 and never think twice. But when you have integrity and good morals like Avake, you make the right decision even when no one is looking. We are fortunate in Demopolis to have many honest students just like Avake.

The school administrators and teachers want students to be in attendance on time and all day. Multiple check-ins and early dismissals can add up to missed instructional time. Missed instructional time can lead to students getting behind academically and in need for intervention, private tutoring, or even summer school to catch up. As a reminder, students are allowed 4 parent excuses for check-ins and early dismissals. After 4 parent excuses, check-ins and early dismissals must be accompanied with a doctor’s excuse. An abundance of unexcused check-ins or early dismissals will result in a referral to the early warning truancy program and may lead to a truancy complaint filed with the Marengo County District Judge.
In addition, it is strongly encouraged for parents not to check their children out after 2:00 PM. Late afternoon check-outs cause interruptions in the school day and afternoon traffic flow on each campus. If we can make it to 2:00, then in most cases we can make it all day.

Thank you for taking school attendance seriously and making a free public education a priority in your family and Demopolis, Alabama.
